title: How to Restore Oak Cabinets

steps.headline: Lay drop clothes under the cabinets and all over your work area.
Put on rubber gloves, goggles and a mask that will let you breathe while protecting you from harmful chemical fumes.
Remove the cabinet doors and drawers.
steps.description: Use a screwdriver to take off the hinges as well.

steps.headline: Open a can of chemical stripper.
steps.description: You can purchase it at any hardware store or home improvement store.

steps.headline: Use a paintbrush to paint the exterior side of the cabinet with the stripper.
steps.description: Let it soften the finish for about 15 minutes. The stripper should cause it to gel.

steps.headline: Scrape off the gelled finish with a flat stick or scraper.
steps.description: Begin at the top of the cabinet and scrape downwards, allowing the finish to fall off the sides of the cabinet. Repeat the chemical stripping and scraping on the exterior of all the cabinets you plan to restore.

steps.headline: Apply the stripper to the cabinet doors and scrape off the gelled finish, as you did with the outside of the cabinets.
steps.description: Repeat the process on the exterior of the drawers as well. Lay the cabinet doors across a sawhorse for the best access. Remember to wait 15 minutes after applying the chemical stripper to begin scraping. Scrape from the top to the bottom on the doors, the same way you did on the cabinets.

steps.headline: Sand the cabinets with 100-grit sandpaper.
steps.description: Your sanding motion should go parallel with the grain of the oak. Continue sanding until there is a smooth feel to the wood. All of the finish should be gone, and there should be no grooves or differences in texture after the cabinet is sanded.

steps.headline: Sand the doors and drawers the same way you sanded the cabinets.
steps.description: Remember to sand parallel with the grain of the wood, and continue sanding until the surface is smooth and consistent.

steps.headline: Apply stain to the cabinets.
steps.description: Dip a staining sponge into a can of oak stain and wipe it over the cabinets generously. As soon as you get the stain onto the cabinets, wipe it off with a dry cloth. Stain and wipe the doors and drawers the same way you applied the stain to the cabinets.

steps.headline: Let the stain dry for at least 30 minutes.
Apply a light coat of lacquer to the cabinets.
steps.description: This can often be found in an aerosol spray can for easy application. Hold the can 8 inches (20 cm) away from the cabinet and spray evenly in one direction. Continue spraying the entire cabinet going in one direction and then the other (back and forth instead of one end to the other end) until it is covered with lacquer.

steps.headline: Coat the doors and drawers with lacquer as well.
steps.description: Spray it the same way you did the cabinets.

steps.headline: Allow the lacquer to dry for at least 30 minutes.
Fold a piece of 180-grit sandpaper twice and sand everything; the cabinets, the doors and the drawers.
steps.description: The lacquer should look less shiny and feel smooth when you touch it.

steps.headline: Apply another coat of lacquer.
steps.description: Spray everything the same way you did with the first coat. Let it dry for a full 24 hours. This will allow the finish to set.

steps.headline: Re-hang the cabinet doors and install the drawers.

text: Lay drop clothes under the cabinets and all over your work area.  Put on rubber gloves, goggles and a mask that will let you breathe while protecting you from harmful chemical fumes.  Remove the cabinet doors and drawers. Use a screwdriver to take off the hinges as well. Open a can of chemical stripper. You can purchase it at any hardware store or home improvement store. Use a paintbrush to paint the exterior side of the cabinet with the stripper. Let it soften the finish for about 15 minutes. The stripper should cause it to gel. Scrape off the gelled finish with a flat stick or scraper. Begin at the top of the cabinet and scrape downwards, allowing the finish to fall off the sides of the cabinet. Repeat the chemical stripping and scraping on the exterior of all the cabinets you plan to restore. Apply the stripper to the cabinet doors and scrape off the gelled finish, as you did with the outside of the cabinets. Repeat the process on the exterior of the drawers as well. Lay the cabinet doors across a sawhorse for the best access. Remember to wait 15 minutes after applying the chemical stripper to begin scraping. Scrape from the top to the bottom on the doors, the same way you did on the cabinets. Sand the cabinets with 100-grit sandpaper. Your sanding motion should go parallel with the grain of the oak. Continue sanding until there is a smooth feel to the wood. All of the finish should be gone, and there should be no grooves or differences in texture after the cabinet is sanded. Sand the doors and drawers the same way you sanded the cabinets. Remember to sand parallel with the grain of the wood, and continue sanding until the surface is smooth and consistent. Apply stain to the cabinets. Dip a staining sponge into a can of oak stain and wipe it over the cabinets generously. As soon as you get the stain onto the cabinets, wipe it off with a dry cloth. Stain and wipe the doors and drawers the same way you applied the stain to the cabinets. Let the stain dry for at least 30 minutes.  Apply a light coat of lacquer to the cabinets. This can often be found in an aerosol spray can for easy application. Hold the can 8 inches (20 cm) away from the cabinet and spray evenly in one direction. Continue spraying the entire cabinet going in one direction and then the other (back and forth instead of one end to the other end) until it is covered with lacquer. Coat the doors and drawers with lacquer as well. Spray it the same way you did the cabinets. Allow the lacquer to dry for at least 30 minutes.  Fold a piece of 180-grit sandpaper twice and sand everything; the cabinets, the doors and the drawers. The lacquer should look less shiny and feel smooth when you touch it. Apply another coat of lacquer. Spray everything the same way you did with the first coat. Let it dry for a full 24 hours. This will allow the finish to set. Re-hang the cabinet doors and install the drawers.
